key_0.lead_paragraph: In 1973, Sara Krulwich visited 29 newspapers, looking for a job after graduating from the University of Michigan. She met with male photo editors who mostly scoffed at the idea of a woman as a news photographer. One editor, she said, told her that hiring a woman was like “hiring half a person.”

key_4.snippet: A former Army officer found that women were often the best soldiers he encountered....
key_4.lead_paragraph: Suspended from her position in December, the commandant of the United States Army's drill sergeant school is currently under investigation for an undisclosed personnel issue. Command Sgt. Maj. Teresa L. King was the first female commandant of the school, a somewhat high-profile position that is the source for the Army's pool of drill sergeants. These soldiers, who are typically men, are responsible for training thousands of new recruits each year. Sergeant Major King, known for her keen attention to detail and dogmatic demand for discipline, was named commandant in 2009. Since then, she has enjoyed some well-deserved popularity, including being named to Oprah Winfrey's O Power List, as well as an appearance in the October 2010 issue of O, The Oprah Magazine.
key_4.abstract: A former Army officer found that women were often the best soldiers he encountered.

headline.main: Fighting for Gender Equality on the Battlefield

Years ago on my first job the male supervisor didn't think twice in brushing away my discovery of the pay gap between male and female college graduates in the same job by saying men had to ''support families.''

headline.main: For Pregnant Marathoners, Two Endurance Tests
headline.print_headline: For Pregnant Marathoners, Two Endurance Tests

key_7.snippet: Researchers found that university science professors widely regard female students as less competent than male ones....
key_7.lead_paragraph: Researchers found that university science professors widely regard female students as less competent than male ones.
key_7.abstract: Dr Jo Handelsman study in Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences shows that science professors at American universities widely regard female undergraduates as less competent than male students with the same accomplishments and skills, and are less likely to offer the women mentoring or a job.

headline.seo: Bias Persists Against Women of Science, a Study Says
headline.main: Bias Persists for Women of Science, a Study Finds
headline.print_headline: Bias Persists for Women Of Science, a Study Finds

keywords.name: organizations

key_7.snippet: Hearing that discrimination is common is a license to do it....
key_7.lead_paragraph: Hearing that discrimination is common is a license to do it.
key_7.abstract: Women at Work column by Prof Adam Grant and Sheryl Sandberg, chief operating officer of Facebook, contends American culture's strong gender stereotypes extend beyond image to performance and lead many to believe men are more competent than women; highlights research that shows learning about ubiquity of stereotypes only makes stereotyping worse, unless people are encouraged to correct their biases.

headline.seo: Adam Grant and Sheryl Sandberg on Discrimination at Work
headline.main: When Talking About Bias Backfires
headline.print_headline: When Talking About Bias Backfires

byline.original: By ADAM GRANT and SHERYL SANDBERG

key_7.snippet: The Paycheck Fairness Act addressed the issue of the wage gap among men and women, but it did not get to the central reasons behind wage inequality....
key_7.lead_paragraph: The Paycheck Fairness Act addressed the issue of the wage gap among men and women, but it did not get to the central reasons behind wage inequality.
key_7.abstract: Eduardo Porter Economic Scene column discusses the Paycheck Fairness Act, which addressed the issue of the wage gap between men and women, but was blocked by Republicans in the Senate; says bill would have limited the reasons employers use to justify pay differences, but would have failed to address the central reasons women still earn less than men, including different career paths and the constraints of motherhood.

headline.seo: Motherhood Still a Cause of Pay Inequality
headline.main: Motherhood Still a Cause of Pay Inequality
headline.print_headline: Motherhood Still a Cause Of Pay Inequality

key_7.snippet: As steady full-time jobs with benefits are increasingly elusive, more men are reaching for a chance at the American dream in female-dominated occupations....
key_7.lead_paragraph: As steady full-time jobs with benefits are increasingly elusive, more men are reaching for a chance at the American dream in female-dominated occupations.
key_7.abstract: More men are working in occupations traditionally dominated by women, in a search for financial security; trend started with low-skill jobs, but has spread to areas like nursing and teaching that require more education; eight of the 20 categories where, young, college-educated white men experienced the greatest job growth in the last decade were in so-called pink-collar professions (Series: The New American Job).

headline.seo: Increasingly, Men Seek Success in Jobs Dominated by Women
headline.main: More Men Enter Fields Dominated by Women
headline.print_headline: More Men Enter Fields Dominated by Women

byline.original: By SHAILA DEWAN and ROBERT GEBELOFF

key_7.snippet: Accusations of discrimination are hashed out in conference rooms, and silenced with a check....
key_7.lead_paragraph: Accusations of discrimination are hashed out in conference rooms, and silenced with a check.
key_7.abstract: Op-Ed article by Maureen Sherry suggests main reason women continue to be paid less than men on Wall Street is due to arbitration clauses they are forced to sign upon receiving employment, binding them to settle any job dispute with employer in-house; calls for ban on mandatory arbitration on Wall Street, and right for any woman claiming discrimination or harassment to get her day in public court rather than a settlement check behind closed doors.

headline.main: A Colleague Drank My Breast Milk and Other Wall Street Tales
headline.print_headline: Why Aren’t Women Doing Better on Wall Street?

key_8.snippet: Work done by women pays less because women do it, research shows....
key_8.lead_paragraph: Work done by women pays less because women do it, research shows.
key_8.abstract: The Upshot; Claire Cain Miller Economic View column reacts to research finding that unequal pay gap between women and men is based on perception that work done by women is worth less than that done by men; observes research shows trend has persisted despite elimination of some factors originally thought to have caused it.

headline.main: As Women Take Over a Male-Dominated Field, the Pay Drops
headline.print_headline: Why Women Still Get the Short End of the Dollar

key_8.snippet: Reports of a matriarchy are exaggerated. In many arenas, the progress of women has stalled....
key_8.lead_paragraph: Reports of a matriarchy are exaggerated. In many arenas, the progress of women has stalled.
key_8.abstract: Op-Ed article by author and history teacher Stephanie Coontz disputes notion that middle-class American women are increasingly becoming dominant; contends that in many arenas the progress of women has stalled over the last 15 years.

headline.main: The Myth of Male Decline
headline.print_headline: The Myth of Male Decline

key_8.snippet: Many young women are leaving the labor force to upgrade their skills, while their male counterparts are more likely to take whatever job they can find....
key_8.lead_paragraph: Many young women are leaving the labor force to upgrade their skills, while their male counterparts are more likely to take whatever job they can find.
key_8.abstract: For the first time in three decades there are more young women in school than in the work force; many young women have dropped out of the labor force in order to upgrade their skills, while their male counterparts are more likely to take any job they can find; economists say that the long-term consequence of this trend may be that the next generation of women may have significant advantages over the next generation of men.

headline.seo: Young Women Go Back to School Instead of Work
headline.main: Instead of Work, Younger Women Head to School
headline.print_headline: Instead of Work, Younger Women Head to School

key_8.snippet: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe pledged to make it easier for women who have children to continue careers, rather than leaving the work force....
key_8.lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe pledged to make it easier for women who have children to continue careers, rather than leaving the work force.
key_8.abstract: Japanese Prime Min Shinzo Abe has pledged to make it easier for women with children to continue working; promise is part of his broader effort to reinvigorate economy, which is struggling with twin problems of shrinking population and smaller labor force; Abe has focused on support for child care, which is in short supply, but his policies face added challenge of changing entrenched corporate culture that has been unfriendly to working mothers.

headline.main: To Rescue Economy, Japan Turns to Supermom
headline.print_headline: To Rescue Economy, Japan Turns to Supermom

key_8.snippet: A young officer’s experience shows how far the agency has come in its acceptance of transgender workers....
key_8.lead_paragraph: A young officer’s experience shows how far the agency has come in its acceptance of transgender workers.
key_8.abstract: Editorial examines case of 'Jenny,' transgendered Central Intelligence Agency analyst who successfully transitioned to life as a woman on the job; recounts history of discrimination at agency against gay, lesbian and transgendered employees, shameful legacy that did not begin to improve until the mid-1990s; observes that Jenny's identity is now an afterthought for colleagues, testament to how far agency has come (Series: Transgender Today).

headline.main: Transgender at the C.I.A.
headline.print_headline: Transgender at the C.I.A.

key_9.snippet: Many women are leaving the work force in their peak earning years, a setback for the economy that also bucks a powerful decades-long movement....
key_9.lead_paragraph: Many women are leaving the work force in their peak earning years, a setback for the economy that also bucks a powerful decades-long movement.
key_9.abstract: Many women in their late 40s and early 50s have left work force in years since last recession began, just as they were reaching their peak earning years; trend is setback for the economy that also bucks a powerful decades-long movement of women of all ages into the labor market; causes of unexpected decrease in labor participation include necessity to juggle family needs as well as significant drop in state and local government employment.

headline.main: For Women in Midlife, Career Gains Slip Away
headline.print_headline: Women Quit Jobs in Peak Years, Setback for Them and Economy
